I recently got a new body for my revo that didnt quite fit with the old shorter posts I had on it. So I decided to make my own. There is a long and a short one attached depending on the size of the lift you need.

Who says a 3d printer can't help your new years resolution of staying in shape?  Cyclists in cooler climates will often ride on stationary bike trainers in the winter to keep up their conditioning. This can get kind of boring.  A tablet could provide much needed entertainment if only there was a way to mount it.  This thing was designed to fit my Nexus 7 tablet, but should fit a great number of other devices as well.  It's mostly open on the side so that the ports (and most importantly to me, the headphone jack) are still accessible.  
This design works pretty well for me on a trainer.  I wouldn't recommend using it with rollers as it probably wouldn't be very stable on a moving bike.  Also, I shouldn't have to say this, but don't use this on a bike outdoors.  Your device will fall, and it may break.

Print the parts using settings you feel will make them strong.  Support material is integrated into the model.  
The tablet holders have dovetail joints to attach the tops to the bottoms, I needed to use a utility knife to shave off a thin sliver of material to get everything to fit.  I then used a dab of glue in each joint to make sure the part stayed together.  
After removing the support material, place a nut and bolt through the two parts to each clamp.  You should probably use a washer to ensure that the plastic isn't overly stressed.
Use nuts, bolts, and washers to attach the tablet holders to the clamps.
Mount the clamps on your handlebars, adjust as appropriate, and then secure the clamps with a long nut and bolt.
Ride on my friend!

title: Peristaltic Pump
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A peristaltic pump is used to pump fluids. Its main advantage is that the fluid never get in contact with mechanical parts of the machine as it is contained within a flexible tube.
This peristaltic pump was realized for "Hydroponic L.I.S.A." (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:414271) but it is possible to adapt it for any other machine.

The stepper is a standard Nema stepper for 3D printing
4x 634Z bearings
2x 608Z bearings
1x M8 threaded rod
2x M3 screws to fix the stepper
1x polyurethane tube (the one used for slingshot, outer diameter 6,5mm; inner diameter 2,5mm)

comments.text: Peristaltic pumps are really cool. Happy to see one on here as it's not something i see often in the maker community. I job i worked used them frequently and needed to service them. IMHO it looks like you have too much room between the  bearings and tube. Also I would suggest possibly switching to a 3 or even two bearing model and making the body wider for thicker tubing. Awesome start though!
comments.author: staticbunny

comments.text: how much l/m can it push, and how much head does it generate?
comments.author: R-A

comments.text:
Water flow wasn't what we expected, it was our first experience with peristaltic pumps, but enough for our need (really small hydroponic system). It can pump approximately a glass of water in 2-3 minutes.
If you need more lt/min we suggest you to go with bigger flexible pipes that the one we got (just 2,5mm inside diameter)
comments.author: R-A

comments.text: I got two 4 head units used for aquarium dosing and merged them into one unit, to be controlled with Arduino.  In mine, there is small diameter tubing and 12v motors.  If memory serves me, they only did roughly 1.2ml/sec, though nailing down the accuracy was proving tricky so I abandoned the project for a while.  I like this design, but maybe due to the tubing you used having such thin walls compared to the dia, not as much fluid is moved b/c of flex.  I bet something with slightly thicker walls will give you more flow.  Good build.  A bit bulky in size, but looks to be very functional.  I'm actually shopping around looking for a way to merge 8 1/4" OD flex tubes into a PVC fitting so if any of you have seen something along those lines, please fill me in.  I want to get that project going again.
comments.author: piuLAB

author: piuLAB

description.text: This hat holder has a hole to allow easy attaching to a wall that has a capped screw mounted. The same mechanism could be found in many old mechanical wall clocks.

If Makerbot and Reprap had a demon child- This is a beast. Built with both the reprap and makerbot as references.
The biggest concern i had building this, was getting it to work with ball chain instead of belts, and with a lot of back and forth testing this out it finally works like a charm. I had a 440x300mm heating element custom made by some "expert", that ended up not to spesifications. The result was only 80Â°C, so i had to figure something out so that the ABS wouldnt end up curling,
and wet sanding sheet was the answer. Now the object sticks to the platform like tongues to metal during wintertime. I got it up and running with just prints from a makerbot, but now some of the pieces are remade on itself. This is still just a prototype and a work in progress. Specs: Size: 800 mm (W) x 800 mm (D) x 600 mm (H)
Build Envelope: 500 mm (W) x 300 mm (D) x 250 mm (H)
Platform: Heated to 80Â°C
Surface: Wet sanding sheet 600 grits
Drive system: Ball chain (3.5mm)

When using the ball chain pulley you have to edit the machines.XML in the replicatorG folder to: axis id="x" length="300" maxfeedrate="5000" scale="4.45"
axis id="y" length="300" maxfeedrate="5000" scale="4.4"
axis id="z" length="300" maxfeedrate="150" scale="270"

comments.text: how did you figure out what the correct 'scale' figures were in the machines.xml? '
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I mounted a black marker to the carriage and had it draw on paper. In ReplicatorG i had it move 50mm in X and Y directions, i then measured the result and either increased or decreased the numbers in machine.xml until i got a matching result between repG and on paper:)

description.text:
Shows the manufacturing and operation of an RGB light using a digital LED strip controlled by an application by means of a serial comunication: Bluetooth, Zigbee or USB.
Part list: wooden support (optional), RGB digitally-addressable LED strip (from Adafruit or Pololu...), microcontroller (arduino pro mini, for example), Bluetooth .OR. Xbee .OR. an USB wire. Below, you can find a demo video and the link to the git repository with all the code involved: software and firmware. Questions or suggestions are welcome More info: http://madebyfrutos.wordpress.com/2013/01/07/my-rgb-lamp/
YouTuve video: http://youtu.be/yhes_WA0_Wo
Code on Git: https://github.com/astromaf/MyRGBLamp

After activating the bluetooth, open the appliacation to control the lamp.
The program shows a hue palette divided into 30 rods: one for each LED from the strip.
Click and drag the mouse cursor to make your own patterns. Clicking on a rod while the spacebar is pressed removes the color (switch off this led). Part list: wooden support (optional), RGB digitally-addressable LED strip (from Adafruit or Pololu...), microcontroller (arduino pro mini, for example), Bluetooth .OR. Xbee .OR. an USB wire. Below, you can find a demo video and the link to the git repository with all the code involved: software and firmware. Questions or suggestions are welcome
Hippo

venturi
This is a simple venturi injector for injecting air into a fluid stream.

This is the 4th redesign of my cubicle coat hook. It is designed to rest on top of a cubicle which is approximately 25mm thick at the top with slightly poofy walls - almost like a pillow top mattress. It has a tab which is intended to slide underneath the fabric side which is intended to help minimize the likelihood of an object coming off the cubicle wall when grabbing your jacket.

We printed this on a Replicator 2 with default settings and high resolution with the Makerbot software version 1.1.0.55. On a raft, but needs no supports. It works pretty well. I don't know what other settings would be for other machines.

title: iPad Mini Holder for Car Rear view mirror

description.text:
Two parts.
Part 1 Holds iPad Mini
Part 2 Mounts to Mirror with tabs and Velcro strips
The two sections get connected with a 1/4" bolt and nut.

Print each part.
Connect the Mirror section to your rear view mirror with some Velcro straps. This is designed to fit a Tahoe.
Slide iPad Mini into other part, bolt them together with w 1/4" bolt.
Loosen bolt to adjust horizontally, use the mirror adjustment for additional flexibility. I made this for use as a Rear view mirror replacement. It streams video from a camera placed on the back windshield. I use it when the back of my truck is full of stuff and I can't see out of the back.

Lisa is a hydroponic system for your home, it is like a self sustainable ecosystem.
You can cultivate different kind of plants with an automatic system controlled by an android app. You have the possibility taking care of the plat by automatically switching on and off the led and regulating the water flow.
A possible development consist of replacing the pump with a peristaltic pump activated by a arduino hygrometric sensor.
It was born during the EcoFuturo fair in Alcatraz (Gubbio Italy), in one week about designing, hacking, 3d printing and self production.
It's the result of a collaboration among people with different competences and interests (we love that).

Electronics:
1x bluetooth module HC-05
2x relay
1x 100W hydroponic light
1x RTC
Other stuff:
1x rod
1x fish bowl
1x pump (alternative: peristaltic pump http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:414192) Screws:
9 x m3 screws
6 x m4 screws
2 x m4 nuts
2 x m6 nuts
Test

I designed these in Tinkercad to fit the Munchkin theme.  They help keep track of what level you are in the game.  The instructions literally tell you to use whatever you want for this purpose.  I don't think they planned on someone 3D printing a set of pieces, but here we are!  Maybe one day I'll create pieces that interlock and are easily stack-able to distract the other players and ensure their swift defeat!

These print quite easily without any support.  If you flip the model upside-down, and have your slicer skip printing the top layer (and set your infill to 0%), you can create a hollow model that is sturdy and uses less plastic.  However, they don't stack as nicely when they aren't solid.

  • make settings in openscad
  • export .Stl
  • Slice with software that export g-coge (i used Kiss)
    • use absolut movement.
    • Support = everewhere
    • Support fill = 50%
    • Fill = 95%
  • open gcode with an editor(i used Notepad++)
    -search for z=4.00 or "z4.00" (z=half hight)
    • search for end gcode
    • deleat everything in between
  • Print

description.text: I designed this hellgate model for a short film called Back Story. When I got my Zortrax M200 recently I was on the lookout for something that would be fun to print on the big side. So here we are. You can see the sculpture in my portfolio here: http://ianstrandberg.com/portfolio/115/

I scaled mine so the head is about 18 cm (7 inches) wide and printed with a z-height of 0.19.  Supports are required.  A raft is recommended if your printer has any issues with warping.  
It is not designed to be free standing.  It will have to be glued to a base or a backboard.  Could make a cool bookend.

title: Smoothieboard 5driver model
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is just a little model i made up to plan my new 3d printer. Thought i could share the model with the community in case someone else is as obsessed with detailed planning as i am...
This is the 5-driver board that measures roughly 105x130mm. I mostly used upright Combicom connectors from Phonenix Contact. The raw board data was extracted from the Eagle files with Altium Designer and then saved as STEP-file to be imported in the CAD tool where it was populated with some of the most important connectors and the big power FETs. Thats where the funky measurements come from, the original was most probably made up in imperial units.
STEP-file is attached too, so you can probably just swap out the connectors for whatever you fancy.

A remix of a reindeer to fit a 3mm LED (+ sleigh (see sources))
See instructions for more info.

Needed:
1 3D printed reindeer
1 CR2032 battery
1 3mm LED
some left over cable
soldering iron
patience :)
Instructions:
  • Print the STL file
  • clean up support (this includes the hole from the nose to the back)
  • solder some cable to the LED so you can run it to the back (where the battery sits). (pro tip: use heatshrink tube to protect the LED leads).
  • run the cable + LED through the hole.
  • secure the battery in the slot, making sure that the cable is touching the battery (make sure the positive and negative leads match).
  • place the lid on the battery slot.
    Side notes:
    • Be REALLY carefull with the antlers when cleaning the support and working on the print. They are pretty delicate.
    • Print in the pictures was made using an UP! mini using ABS, please upload your makes to show it also works on other printers with other filaments.
    • The battery lid doesn't fit 100%, some fiddling may be required.

title: Printrbot LC+ v2 auto-leveling probe bracket

description.text: Auto-leveling probe bracket for Printrbot LC+ v2 (not 2.1) with wooden geared extruder. Attaches to the extruder carriage via the two front-facing screws on the inside of the hotend compartment.

I'll OpenSCAD this eventually to make it parametric. Maybe.
Print with somewhat dense infill to avoid vibrations during fast carriage movements. I used 90%, but that might have been overkill. It was strong enough to crank down on the screws to make sure it didn't move, though.
UPDATE: 90% was actually a little underkill. It will sag a bit with heat, and give you strange readings between prints. I'm trying again at 100% and will probably need to re-think the layout a bit.
probe_bracket5 has shortened screw panel (to fit extruder width) and a support which comes out around the front of the bracket to give it extra strength. Print with supports.

Per tutti coloro che non sono in grado di eseguire la modifica alla stampante per realizzare il piatto riscaldato come descritto in uno dei miei progetti ho realizzato un nuovo piano riscaldato autonomo.
La struttura è di alluminio su tre punti con molle e il piano viene riscaldato con un a resistenza a 230V in gomma siliconica. Il piano viene fornito con display pre programmare tempo e temperatura. Per chi possiede una stampante WASP basta appoggiarlo sul piano, fissarlo con 4 pinze a molla fornite, livellarlo e stampare. La planarità è garantita da un vetro. Sul vetro consiglio di usare il nastro di carta blu. Per il PLA bastano 50° l'adesione è garantita. Ricordatevi però di mettere un ; (puntoevirgola) davanti alla riga di comndo G 28 Z0 per evitare di sfondare il piano oppure fatevi la modifica del micro finecorsa asse Z. La programmazione di tempo e temperatura è semplice ed intuitiva. La scheda funziona fino a 24V DC e può alimentare direttamente un piatto PCB con sensore di temperatura. Se siete interessati all'acquisto del kit completo oppure solo alla scheda con display scrivetemi. [email protected]

Ho progettato il piano riscaldato in lamiera di alluminio allo scopo di creare un oggetto facile da montare e smontare che fosse facile da utilizzare e che consentisse di avere un piano riscaldato indipendente dalla stampante, se volete ci potete scaldare la piadina! La temperatura e il tempo possono essere cambiati anche durante la stampa. Quando il piatto ha raggiunto la temperatura programmata parte il conteggio del tempo e quando il tempo programmato è stato raggiunto il piatto si spegne da solo.

comments.text: Ciao, te volevo chiedere solo se è possibile "collegare" il piano alla stampante in modo da controllarlo con lo slicer direttamente dal pc, anzichè manualmente... solo per curiosità. Comunque mi piace l'idea e sono interessato al piano

description.text:
This adapter bracket lets you precisely align a 2.5" SATA drive in a 3.5" hard drive caddy so that the SATA connector is in the correct position to mate with the backplane.
The model is designed for a snug fit to my Kingston SSD's, I would recommend you compare the model dimensions to your own drive before printing, particularly the height dimension.
The holes are sized at the correct tap drill size for a 6-32 UNC thread. If you do not have a 6-32 tap (I didn't) you can just use a screw, it works fine.

description.text:
Here's a really quick and easy 3D-printable screw-in front lenscap design, set-up as a customizer application. Less than $0.15 worth of materials are used to make a typical size lenscap, yet they work well and can even double as color references.
An Instructable gives the details: http://www.instructables.com/id/3D-Printed-Screw-In-Front-Lenscaps/ Note: An improved version of this is now available as http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1563812

Although the customizer parameters are well commented, please see the Instructable, http://www.instructables.com/id/3D-Printed-Screw-In-Front-Lenscaps/ , I wrote giving the details -- especially about sizing the lenscap.
Creating STLs

The OpenSCAD file has fairly obvious parameters that can be set using the Customizer or by manual editing of the file. You will need to have the Write.scad library in order to create the labels using stand-alone OpenSCAD to make STL files.
Filament Choice

Pick a plastic that has a neutral color so you can use the lenscap as a color reference. The Rosewill Grey PLA used here is quite close to a neutral gray. White or gray PLA, or clear T-Glase, are what I'd recommend.
Printing Issues

It's a straightforward and fast print, although it does have tight precision constraints on the thread diameter and pitch. PLA tends to work better than ABS because ABS doesn't hold dimensions as well over a large diameter; I also find using no more that 40% fill gives less distortion of the parts as they cool. The 0.75mm pitch typical of filter screw threads is really much too fine to be printing on typical consumer-level printers, but this uses a slightly tweaked metric-compatible thread design that prints easily in PLA on my MakerGear M2 even with 0.25mm extrusion. The printed thread is quite shallow, but it's more than sufficient to hold the cap in.

comments.text: Would you mind telling me how to adjust the height/number of threads? I'd like it to go a little deeper but I can't find where that's controlled in the SCAD file.
comments.author: ayryq

comments.text:
I think I've found it. All my modifications are at the end of module print_part0()
There's a "tall" parameter called in male_thread() which I increased from 3 to [something large],
There's a bounding cylinder (actually a cone) called in the last line of the module (r1=(dia/2)+4) in which I increased h=3 to h=6 to get 6mm of threads.
Also if you want, commenting out the cylinder in between (r=dia-3)/2) results in a solid instead of hollow lens cap.

description.text:
I cleaned up arabon's nice model found here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:24706
There were a few portions of the model that weren't complete which caused the Makerware slicer to produce some strange artifacts.
The holes are patched now and the print looks great!
Edit: I printed arabon's model to find that the outer diameter of the holder was off. I inverted that so it now fits a standard ~76mm (3 in. if you swing that way) roll of packaging tape. The new model is now uploaded in place of the old one.
Edit #2: The teeth easily break off and need to be reworked a bit. Printing with a higher infill or with a stronger filament (nylon) may prevent this from occurring. Suggestions and comments welcome.

Print without rafting (as it may tear off the teeth)
Support material is necessary.
Print time should be around 5 hours on a Replicator 2 with standard resolution.
Material cost is around 53 grams or 0.12 lbs

I hit the store to buy a ceiling mount for my Optoma HD66, but the store was out of stock.  So I designed up this one, and printed it out.  It's designed specifically for the HD66's slightly odd 100 x 100 x 110 mm triangular M3 mount, but a redesigned ProjectorPlate.stl will let you stick any projector on there.  Swivels in XX, YY and ZZ, and is fairly stable too.

Print it out fairly densely, bolt it up with M5 bolts (Darwin leftovers), and add some fender washers to spread out the loads.  Tighten up the joints until you have a nice level of friction.  Nyloc nuts help a lot.  
Don't forget a safety leash, in case of total failure - I use 650 lb kite line, should do the trick.

Caja para contener la placa electrónica "Bus Pirate" versión 3.6 de sparkfun.com.

Las medidas están optimizadas para imprimirlo con capa de 0.4mm. pero podeis bajaros el fichero fuente que está hecho con el OpenScad para ajustar cualquier medida.

La tapa tiene truco para encajarla sin que se caiga. Una vez imprimida hay que limarle los dos laterales mas largos que es donde apoya la tapa para darles forma de trapecio, con una pequeña inclinación es suficiente.

Ahora a la caja con la punta de un cúter se le rasca los laterales interiores para hacer la misma forma.

Hay que limar lo justo a la tapa para que entre con una ligera presión y esta no haga ni mucha fuerza en los laterales ya que se nota que se deforma la caja, ni tampoco pasarnos pues quedaría corta.
_
Las medidas interiores están bastante ajustadas, de manera que para facilitar que entre la placa electrónica hay que redondear un poco sus puntas ya que en mi caso eran perfectamente cuadradas y la impresora no deja exactamente cuadradas las esquinas interiores de la caja.

description.text: I've had some problems getting my prints to stay flat on the build plate and / or stick to the build plate with my Makerbot Replicator 1. I know that others have to and that solutions have been difficult to find. My solution is to create a custom slicing profile with these raft settings. This method takes longer and uses more plastic for rafts but works consistently. I have an updated version that works better: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:102619

I use ReplicatorG. In ReplicatorG go to "Edit Slicing Profiles..." in the "GCode" menu. Select "Replicator slicing defaults" and click "Duplicate..." Enter a name for your new profile and click "Ok" The Skeinforge Settings window will open. Select "Craft" and then "Raft". Change all of your settings to match mine. "Support Cross Hatch" is optional. Try this on or off and see which works better for the types of things you print. When you are done changing your settings click "Save All" and close the window. Click "Done" in the "Edit Profiles" window. You can always edit your profile again later. Open the file you want to print and position it on the platform. Click "Generate GCode" and make sure that your slicing profile is selected. Then enter your print settings. Object infill: 8%
Layer Height: .25mm
Number of Shells: 2
Feedrate: 40mm/s
Travel Feedrate: 55
Print Temperature: 225 Before you print click the "gcode" tab. Change
M109 S110 T0 (set HBP temperature)
to
M109 S115 T0 (set HBP temperature). [T0 uses right extruder, T1 uses left extruder] A great reference is http://wiki.bitsfrombytes.com/index.php?title=Skeinforge_Raft

comments.text: Did you try blocking the airflow under the extruder fans? I had to use rafts on EVERY print when I first got my Replicator. It wasn't until I placed a strip of kapton tape under the extruder fans that I finally fixed the issue. It seems those fans are blowing air directly onto the print and cooling it down too fast.  Aside from that, I use acetone to clean the surface before prints.
comments.author: cassetti

comments.text: I have heard of this working very well and I will try it.  Thank you!
comments.author: cassetti

comments.text: Let me know how you make out, I don't even need to 'trap' heat with acrylic panels nowadays since I put kapton tape under the fans. Only time I have issues is when my bed isn't level. Aside from that, I only need rafts when I want supports.
comments.author: emhughes

comments.text: Blocking the airflow with kapton tape worked wonders.  Thank you!

description.text:
I am attempting a 3D Printed circuit. I painted this model with conductive glue and I used a wire to attach a CR2032 battery. Many ATTINY chips can be programing using the Arduino IDE.
See http://www.arduino.cc/
http://highlowtech.org/?p=1695
Use Arduino as ISP or In Circuit Programmer.
I tried Makergeeks conductive ABS but is has high resistance so a conductive paint or paste had to be used.
Attiny84 Datasheet:
http://www.atmel.com/Images/doc8006.pdf
At 3V resistors are not really needed to limit current for LED. I tried to use SMT led but I could not get a good connection.
Just learning AutoCAD Inventor and this is my first project. Hopefully more to follow.

I used AutoCAD Inventor and exported to STL. You have to force it to scale in Millimeters in the export options. I have a Flashforge Creator X 3D printer. I printed using PLA at .1mm. I use a glass plate with aquanet hair spray with nozzle at 215 C and 55 C heated bed. I have update my software to the newest Sailfish (7.6 I think).  Most of the time I use makerware software but other options could achieve better results.

description.text: This is a derivate of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3680, which should be consulted for instructions. The only addition of this thing is, that I already had filament on a spool, and did not want to create a wooden spool. Hence I designed a small spindle holder.

Print 2 spindle holders according to the diameter of your spindle. The sketchup file is included for modifications. Mine had a diameter of 52mm. I just put a screw through both to stabilize it a bit and the end of the screw goes through the bearing.
Make sure that your plastic spools has a rim somewhere, so that you can adjust the bearings to follow it.
I also could not find the proper tube, hence I just used a gardening supply water hose. Will see how it works. (Addition: it does not work at all :-( Just to much friction.

comments.text: I tried two different sizes of pvc hose and there was way to much friction.  My Mendel was even starting to climb the filament.  I had built a sweet 8 spindle overhead storage system with the intention of using hoses to guide the filament from each spool to a point directly over the printer.  I felt sorry for the store clerk who cut himself cutting the hose for me which I right now cannot use as-is.  I'm even considering using the long spring of sewer line de-clogging "snake"  (new of course)  They are cheap and flexible and the PLA should slide along nicely on the metal.  Right now I'm using a very ugly piece of conduit that I bent into weird J shape to make one spindle work, but I've got a backlog of other things to do and need to give it a break.  I'm sure we will all prevail when we find the right hose.  I even considered making a long teflon sock to push through the hose and then pushing the filament through that.  If I was happy with rigidity there is always copper tubing.  All readers, stay away from that soft PVC tubing.  Its way too sticky for this application.

Mount for attaching a cooling fan to the RigidBot extruder and a couple of optional fan nozzles. The fan clips into a hinge and can be tilted up for easier nozzle access. I made the extra nozzles to experiment with. I used the following 24v fan at Amazon (the wire polarity needs to be switched so check that before plugging it in). It seems to be a common part and can probably be found at other places for less. For the upper right fan hole, I used a 6-32 flathead machine screw, but other options will work as it threads into the plastic. I use a 1/8" build plate so the fan is designed to clear the clips. If you're not using a build plate, the fan probably may not clear the bed leveling screws (I haven't tried that configuration).

I would recommend turning down the default fan speed, I've noticed that having it too high can reduce the nozzle temperature significantly below what the thermistor reports, especially when using one of the fan ducts.

This is a remix of the track support posted by MobyDisk.  I found it was a little bit narrow to work with all the tracks and the sidewalls were too thin and broke easily.  After a few design iterations I found a version which can survive the knock-it-off-the-desk-onto-the-cement-floor test.  The inverted ribs seem to work great for strength and impact resistance.  Concept will probably be useful elsewhere.  I printed this with 25% fill in white PET+ on a 2014 Type A Machines Series 1.
Simple parametric plate for doing Lego Technic work.  Super useful for those tight, small mechanisms.

I've been printing on a Makerbot Replicator 2 with 0.2mm layers, 80% infill (perhaps overkill, but they print quickly and feel strong, despite being 1mm thick), 2 shells, 235ºC extrusion (black PLA from Makerbot). No rafts, no supports.  It comes out perfectly.

author: demond101

description.text:
My friend got the GoPro 3-way and I thought I could just have some fun and design a similar one.
First design looks good but I still need to add bolt holders and resize the joints. Also after the print it seemed a bit flimsy so I will make the walls a bit thicker.
Hope it turns out great once I'm done.
Update V2
I re made the whole thing from scratch and it turned out better, still have some little things to tweak but this V2 works already. I decided to get rid of the screw base and went for a simpler approach for now, I will probably add the mini tripod later.
I unfortunately broke it while testing the strength of the joints so pictures don't show me holding it, but it felt solid.
The handle has two holes as the higher one is the one that works directly with the GoPro housings.
I will probably redesign it again from scratch with a more streamline design. Hope you guys like this version.

August 6, 2014
Re-disign looks good, printable and works great. Probably use good infill for rigidity and I suggest supports. It uses the same nut and bolt size as the regular go pro but you will need longer ones for two joints as they are thicker to accommodate the sturdiness of the modular handle.
August 2, 2014 - Well, Do not print yet unless you want to make custom housing for the GoPro as I didn't make sure of the size of the outer diameter of the end joints.
They all snap together just fine, just don't fit any GoPro accessories, so I have to resize a little.
I am glad that everything snapped and worked but the designs still need some work. they are a bit messy and not optimized.
Feel free to mod them if you want, or hopefully you do a better design.
I will post the updates when I have a chance to fix them, also will make the walls a bit thicker as they are a bit flimsy at the moment.
Borrowed the handle design from http://www.thingiverse.com/aubenc Tap Holder Hollow Handle

author: frickmystr

description.text:
This is a jumping shell for Sphero. I really want to get a hand on a sphero to try this design. Here is what I think my shell will do :
  • induce some cool random displacements
  • crazy landings after jumps
  • off-road adventures : move on almost any terrain (sand, rocks, grass, small obstacles)
  • offer a whole new programming challenge

Print 2 copies of the file with support materials.
Press fit 8 3x3x3 neodymium magnets in the small cubic holes at the equator. Verify that the two hemispheres attract themselves securely.
Hot glue 26 small metallic springs in their locations.
Have fun!

comments.text: Wouldn't the magnets risk tripping the reset switch that is specifically intended to be triggered by a magnet?
comments.author: GamerGorman20

comments.text: The magnetic forces that reset the Sphero act perpendicularly to the sphere. The magnetic forces holding the ball shut are acting tangentially to the sphere. These forces are both very small. It is unlikely the magnets will affect the reset switch, though rigorous testing may prove otherwise.

title: Samsung Galaxy Note 3 Case w/ Cover, Magnetized

description.text:
UPDATE 10-15-2014
.
I uploaded a new version of the cover that gets rid of a small gap in the bottom corners, as brought to my attention by user Kareesmoon.
.
This is a variation of my Ultimate Samsung Galaxy Note 3 case. The difference is this one does not have the Sugru bumpers.
.
Here are the other variations:
  • Ultimate (Magnets, Cover, Bumpers) :
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:407517
  • No Cover (Sugru Bumpers, No Magnets):
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:424089
  • No-Frills (No bumpers, no cover, no magnets):
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:415418
    .
    I designed the case in three parts so that printers with small build areas (6"x6") such as the Printrbot Simple Metal could still print it.
    .
    The case features a protective cover with holes cut out to show the time and the music/audiobook/podcast navigation buttons. Now you can check the time in a theatre without distracting your fellow movie-goers!
    .
    The cover is held on by tiny magnets. You can purchase them for under 3 bucks here: http://amzn.to/1oqjeMp
    I also added magnets to the back of the case so you can place the cover on the back when you're using the phone. The back magnets also allow you to use the cover as a stand. (See pictures.)
    .
    This case is designed to fit the Note 3 WITHOUT the original back piece. You can still access the battery by sliding off the two sections.
    .
    I initially printed a hole in the cover that allowed you to take pictures with the cover attached to the back, but I took this off because I realized I am always going to take the cover off when taking pictures.

Parts list:
  • 1/8" x 1/16" magnets, quantity 18.. http://amzn.to/1oqjeMp
  • Epoxy Adhesive, such as Loctite 5 Minute Instant Mix: http://amzn.to/1tqn1MR
    .
    1. Print the Top, Bottom, and Cover using support structures for the Top and Bottom. I highly recommend InTheGarage's Slic3r settings here: http://www.camwatt.com/printrbot-simple-metal-slic3r-settings.html
      .
    2. Clean out the support structures using pliers. Fine tune with a Dremel and sandpaper. Be very careful around the openings. Keep testing until you achieve a snug fit. (Remove Note 3 back before sliding on case. This case doesn't use the original back.) I added a half millimeter extra of length to the edges where the Top and Bottom meet in order to get a gapless fit. You may need to sand these areas to achieve a perfect fit.
      .
    3. Lightly Dremel the magnet holes. There are 6 holes on the front of the case, 6 holes on the cover, and 6 holes on the back of the case. You want a tight fit. For some reason, even though the back case holes are sized the same as the other holes, they may print a little large. Just use a little extra glue for these in step 5.
      .
    4. Insert the magnets ( http://amzn.to/1oqjeMp ), securing with the adhesive of your choice. I recommend Epoxy Adhesive, such as Loctite 5 Minute Instant Mix available at Home Depot or here: http://amzn.to/1tqn1MR. The polarity is EXTREMELY important. The front case magnets should all go in one direction. The back and cover case magnets need to go in the opposite direction of the front case magnets.
      .
    5. If the cover is warped, pour hot water over it and bend to fix the warp. If this doesn't work, put it inside the oven at 200 degrees for a minute, then remove and bend out the warp.
      .
    6. Remove the Note 3's original back piece and slide the case right over the exposed back. This case does not use the original back. You can easily access the battery and sd card by sliding off your new case's top and bottom.
      .
      Enjoy the case! Let me know if you have any suggestions for improvement.

description.text:
After making a delicious pitcher of mudslides the other day, I disassembled the blender pitcher and put all the parts in the dishwasher. I was disappointed to see that the little tabs that held the cap to the lid of the pitcher had broken.
It took me a few minutes to think about how to model this in OpenSCAD. It took a few more minutes to actually model it. I wish I could say the same about OpenSCAD compile and render. That took over an hour at $fn = 50.
The new cap works and fits very nicely. It prints like a breeze with no issues. I actually think my printed cap is a better fit and a better design than the original. The little nubs I made for locking the cap into the lid are much stronger than the tabs were on the original cap. These nubs will not be breaking off for any reason.

Nothing special to do here. Just print it with your favorite settings. I printed mine at 10% fill, 3 shells and a speed of 40 and layer height of .2 using ReplicatorG. With those settings it took about an hour and a half to print out.

title: Handle. Created for a surfski Paddle shaft grip.

description.text:
Select the file with the number in mm closest to the width of your closed fist excluding your thumb,
I tried the customiser but it failed: my model only compiles in wire frame mode in openscad. I've put up some different sizes for people instead. Compared to my fingers a lot of guys have troll fingers.
As compiled, fits a 28.52mm diameter shaft.
Print with a 1mm brim. Best one at a time, I tried a batch and got missed steps, it's a fairly straight forward print on it's own though.
You'll probably want to put some tape around it too (on the paddle) to be absolutely sure it doesn't slip. For anyone who's paddled sea kayaks, multisport kayaks or surfskis, you'll know that wing paddles need fairly precise control of blade angle. There are high density neoprene? foam grips you can buy and also tape-on strips you can buy to make the paddle shaft eccentric but as an inventor, I've not been happy with any of the current options. Most people fit some sort of grip on the right hand side only and go with a 90 degree paddle twist between ends, I use something closer to 40 degrees difference which allows me to lock both hands to the paddle shaft.
Note that with a typical adjustable paddle, for the right side (Orka) the grip (if printed in PLA) won't fit past the adjuster and collar without breaking. Warm it with a paint stripping air gun on the low setting, slip it past the adjusting collar and then heat again and squeeze closed around the shaft again. If you are using ABS or nylon it should open far enough without these precautions.

Print at a layer height of half your nozzle diameter for good results.
Use a 1mm brim, this is a tall print and needs a bit of extra grip from the brim.

Small caving lamp with one LED - it's the first design - I will make update in the future.
All the parts are in ABS except the green (PLA) but everything can be print in both materials.
Layer height 0.25mm but will work with different value

Driver : acm7135 (search image on google to find supplier) it's an 1 w - 350mA linear driver.
Recommended use in 1W mode (350 mA) as the body is in plastic - it has very few thermal dissipation.
Switch : search for KW12 or similar. Generally used as end-stop.
Led : Cree XP
Optic : LXP (height max = 14.6mm) to fit in the lamp
Small o-ring to tight the actuator +sealing.
Li-Ion 18650 battery x 2
Small JST connector used in RC
O-ring for Lamp : 38mm x 1.5mm
Battery cover o-ring : 1.5mm x 20mm
Round piece of plexiglass (or other transparent stuff) 44mm x 3mm
Small oring on the cable glands. Pressed this o-ring to avoid the cable to slip and seals.
Some M3 nuts + screws and small plastic screw (2.5mm) to mount the cable glands.
2 x M4 nuts + screws to hold the lamp bracket (tried without it and it works)
The support is used to mount the led + optic + regulator + switch - wire everything and finally insert into the lamp. When inserted in the lamp you can insert the end of the cable and solder.
To maintain the box cover I used an elastic cord 4mm. Same to fix the lamp and battery box on the helmet. You can alos use tire wraps to mount on the helmet.

title: Spool Holder for P3Steel or Prusa i3 single frame

description.text: This is a remix of the Spool holder for the Prusa i3 aluminium frame by iPadNanito. We made one for our i3 but our new printer is a P3Steel, which has a steel frame of a different width and thickness. We changed the openSCAD code for the Frame Support to make the frame width and thickness variable so you should be able to use this spool holder design for either printer.

Edit the Spoolholder_p3s_Frame_Support.scad and change the variable frame_width to the width (vertical size) of your printer's frame and the variable frame_thickness to the thickness of the frame. You will probably want to print these parts scaled to 102% (depending on the material you use, we used ABS) because they are a very tight fit. Print 2x Bearing_Support and 2x Frame_Support.
Hardware needed:
  • 4 x 2cm M3 screws
  • 4 x M3 nuts
  • 4 x M8 nuts
  • 2 x 608zz Bearings
  • 3 x Threaded rods about 15 cms each

description.text:
Dokdo is the easternmost territory of Korea and situated 87.4km to the southeast of Ulleungdo Island and 216.8km to the east of Jukbeon of the East Coast.
As it is 157.5km to the northwest of Oki Island of Shimane Prefecture of Japan, Japan cannot see Dokdo from Oki Island when we can see Dokdo from Ulleungdo Island on a clear day.
Dokdo has been created by volcanic activities.
It is not one island, but consists of two large islands Dongdo and Seodo and 89 small islands around them.
Dokdo's coordinates are 131?52'10.4" East Longitude and 37?14'26.8" North Latitude for Dongdo and 131?5'54.6" East Longitude and 37?14'30.6" North Latitude for Seodo. You can see more about Dokdo here : http://en.dokdo.go.kr/pages/main/

description.text:
The Cateye Velo 5 and 8 are nice cheap and small bicycle computers that have a big button sticking out the front. If you hold down the button for a few seconds it resets most of the data on the unit. 
It's far too easy for stuff to accidently press the button and erase your ride data when the computer is in a bag or pocket. That's why I made this little laser cut glue-on part on that makes it harder for random objects to press the button. It doesn't get in the way when the computer is on the bike.
DXF now uploaded, as promised.

The front of the velo 8 is curved, so I recommend cutting this out of 2mm acrylic, which has the right amount of flexibility for a good fit. 3mm may also work but it's harder to get the curve.
After you've cut it out, put some superglue on the back, line it up with the button and screen and push the middle until the glue dries. Most excess glue should disperse out of the holes. It's fiddly so try not to glue your fingers together!

description.text:
So I decided I'd use my makerbot to make my girlfriend a new bike light for her birthday. I've been using the new sketchup's solid modeling tools, which are extremely useful and quite fun if you have access to them. The only problem I have with them is the difficulty of editing components once they've been fused together. Additionally, I worried the light I got might not be bright enough. I've seen a few bike lights on thingiverse, but they all seem to be for one particular type of flashlight. So I decided to make my design a little more modular and easy to adapt to most any kind of flashlight. As of now there are 3 components:
The main light housing - I made this to fit a small LED flashlight, but if you scale up the size of the cylinder, or push a hole through the bottom of it, you could make it pretty easy to adapt to any other flashlight. the bike attachment - this should fit most handlebars, but would be pretty easy to scale up or reshape for other ones the connecters - these connect the main light housing and the bike attachment. One gets printed attached to each other component. keep these the same size relative to one another So if you want to modify it, just edit each individual component in sketchup to make it fight your bike or light! Again, I found the solid modeling tools to be invaluable in sticking it all together, but you should have the tools to do most of it even with the free version.

Everything can be made in one print, or separately if you prefer. Just put the bike attachment over your handlebars (and optionally secure it with a bolt and nut if you need to tighten it), put a light in the main light housing, and slide the attachments together. Easy.

description.text:
Crocodile Medallion
https://youtu.be/eOrYGYF_0h8

This is my take on a No-Hob Extruder. This was loosely derived from profezzorn's extruder: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:28430
however I only used the concept of using a bit, rather than a hobbed bolt. I basically redesigned each piece to make it more compact allowing a small bit more Y axis clearance. I also provided a lead-in chamfer for the filament on the main extruder body to keep from binding. The mounting pattern is designed with a Budashnozzle in mind. This is designed for 1.75 filament. Source files are SolidWorks files. I have included those, along with a STEP file of the full Assembly. STL files of the printed pieces are also included. I will update this a bit later with the full functionality explanation, BOM, and instructions. I tried to keep all hardware SAE except for the three screws for the Nema17. The hobbed bolt is replaced with a #115 Dremel bit that can be bought for ~$5 at WalMart. All bearings are standard R2 bearings, that way you don't have two different sizes. And it uses a floating barrel nut to tighten the hinge. This can be bought for cheap at Lowes in their hardware section in a furniture accessory drawer. BOM:
Qty:1) 1/4-20 SHCS 5/8" length
Qty:1) 1/4-20 x 3/8" dia x 5/8" length barrel nut (Hillman Group item#137362; purchase at Lowes ~$1.15)
Qty:1) 10-24 FHCS 1-1/8" length
Qty:1) 10-24 Nylon inserted lock nut
Qty:1) #115 Dremel bit (Walmart ~$5)
Qty:3) R2 bearings (1/8"ID x 3/8"OD x 5/32"W)
Qty:1) 1/8" dowel pin x 3/4" long
Qty:3) 8-32 set screws 5/16" long
Qty:3) 8-32 machine screw hex nuts
